item.title: Tokyo | Chinese mne accused of misrepresenting meeting statements
item.description: The Japanese government announced yesterday that it presented a formal protest to China for “misrepresented” observations made by Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba during a meeting with Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi. Wang and Ishiba met last Friday in Tokyo, at a reception of courtesy organized by the Japanese leader, on the eve of a trilateral meeting between the Japan, South Korea and China foreign ministers, with the aim of promoting future cooperation between the three neighboring countries. After the meeting, the Chinese Foreign Ministry issued a statement stating that Ishiba "fully recognizes the important meaning" of the four documents signed between the two nations, when the deciplind of diplomatic relations in 1972, and that the Japanese leader "respects the positions defined by the Chinese party." Japan urged Beijing to “immediately withdraw” the statement, which “does not resist” the facts, yesterday said Japanese government spokesman Yoshimasa Hayashi at a press conference. Hayashi considered "unfortunate" that the Chinese government issued a statement that "does not correspond to the truth." The Japanese Foreign Ministry also condemned the Chinese statement in a note, stating that during the meeting with Wang, Ishiba “stressed the need to reduce concerns” in bilateral relations, including “the situation in the east of China”, “ensuring the safety of Japanese citizens in China” and raising Chinese restrictions on Japanese seafood importation.

item.title: Social Security | Coutinho defends the regime update
item.description: Deputy José Pereira Coutinho requires the government to review the Social Security System to cease to exist discrimination with the elderly with disabilities. In the written interplies handed over to the Executive, the deputy and president of the Macao Public Function Association (ATFPM) spoke of one of the allegedly discriminatory situations, noting that “a citizen who, since youth, receives a subsidy for disability and reaches the elderly, should have the right to accumulate it with the elderly pension”. In addition, Coutinho states that he has been confronted, through the Citizens Care Office, with "a growing number of support requests from disabled residents, especially those who, reaching the elderly, are faced with a significant reduction in income." "This situation proves to be particularly alarming to those who are not entitled to the pensions of the elderly," he said. According to the deputy, “disabled citizens who reach legal age to be considered elderly are, by definition, individuals who have long -term impediments, physical, mental, intellectual or sensory, limiting their full participation in society, on equal conditions for other elderly”. Review the law In this sense, the deputy says it is “imperative” that “the current norms governing the granting of pensions to disabled citizens who affect the elderly”, since “it is essential to ensure that all citizens, regardless of their condition, have access to rights that promote dignity and quality of life”. "Considering that the relevant legislation is fundamental, in order to ensure that disabled citizens have the right to review the pension to the elderly, I question whether the government will update and modernize the current social security regime that is manifestly disabled taking into account the decade and a half of validity of Law 4/2010 [Social Security Regime]," he said.

item.title: Legionella | Tourist in serious condition
item.description: A 58 -year -old tourist is in serious condition due to a Legionella infection, known as Legionaries' disease. The infection was diagnosed on Saturday at the Conde de São Januário Hospital Center, and the patient has a history of chronic diseases. According to the report presented by the health authorities, the man traveled inland with his family on 10 March. On the other side of the border went to the doctor, after having had fever but did not show improvements. He returned to Macao on March 19, having a shortage of breath, which made it entry into the Conde São Januário Hospital Center. On March 20, the patient resorted to hospital medical assistance, having been diagnosed with pneumonia in both lungs, which led to the need to connect to the mechanical fan. The next day, the analyzes to the expectoration presented a positive result for Legionella, with complications for respiratory failure. item.title: Macau Pass | Thousands of elderly people carried a card for discounts
item.description:
Early in the early hours of the morning, seniors formed lines at the door of the services to change or carry Macau Pass cards and access the discounts of the great consumption award. Until 1pm, more than 22,200 elderly people had already enjoyed the benefits of the consumption incentive program
Even before opening the doors, a line with about half hundred people was at the entrance of the Macau Pass Service Center in the Preta Areia, announcing the beginning of another round of the consumption award, which began yesterday. Before starting the initiative to distribute consumer coupons to residents, to boost local businesses in neighborhoods away from tourist circuits, more than 10,000 residents asked to change Macau Pass to the elderly, 6,000 of which already had the card ready to use. The rest, in addition to residents who wanted to charge the card to access the 300 -Patacas automatic discount and start benefiting from the 50 percent discount on purchases, have been hosted on Macau Pass stores, as well as the various service stations to carry the cards. The Director of Economics and Technological Development Services (DSEDT), Yau Yun Wah, revealed that until 1 pm yesterday, more than 22,200 elderly people had already taken advantage of discounts under the initiative, according to the Chinese channel of Radio Macau. The official said the process was running without problems. However, some elderly people waiting in the center of the center of Macau Pass in the black sand indicated that the earlier opening of the store would have made life easier for residents. An elderly woman said to the public broadcaster that she took off to the store to receive the new card, but that the place was full of residents who wanted to carry the card, see her balance, order second cards of cards, which resulted in a situation chaotic. In the immediate vicinity of the Macau Pass Service Center in the Preta Areia, the resident line clogged buildings of buildings, shops and parking parks. Attention to fraud The DSEDT director also stated that the government will be aware of fraudulent activities during the consumer incentive campaign and that a supervision mechanism was created together with financial institutions with payment applications to prevent consumers from buying something online to access the draw and then cancel the transaction. If activities of this genre are detected, residents will be prevented from participating in the coupon draw for the fraudulent transaction. The president of the Macao Commercial Association, Frederico MA Chi Ngai, was optimistic about the impact of the major consumption award on small and medium enterprises. The leader of the association that organizes the initiative with the government advanced to the Chinese channel of Radio Macau that about a hundred traders plans to add a discount campaign to the consumer incentive program, and that more traders are expected to follow the example.

item.title: Maternity | APPLIED ATTRIBUTION OF FAMILY ASSEMBLY
item.description:
Given the fall of birth, the associations ask the government of Sam Hou Fai to increase the number of support to families. In addition to the birth allowance, currently 5,418 Patacas, the creation of a family allowance and the extent of maternity and paternity licenses are asked
The General Association of Macao Women and the People's Youth Association have defended the assignment of families' allowances to help local families face increasing financial charges. Through a statement, Loi I Weng, vice president of the Association of Women, indicated that there are currently about 23 provinces in the interior to distribute subsidies. For example, the city Hefei, in Anhui province, distributes a single allowance to couples with two or three children, with a value from 2,000 Renminbis to 5,000 Renminbis. In turn, the authorities of the city Jinan, in the province of Shandong, distribute monthly support to families who have two or three children of 600 Renminbis per child, until they have three years. In Macao, Loi I Weng acknowledged that there is a birth allowance, currently in the amount of 5,418 patacas. However, LOI argues that the amount must be increased and the distribution of a family allowance must be considered, having as reference the value of the allowance for caregivers or the family of civil servants, which have the value of 2,175 patacas and 940 patacas, respectively. For its part, the vice president of the Tam Sio Pang Youth Association also defended the idea of ​​childhood assistance. Heard by the newspaper or Mun, the head of the Macao's Subordinate Alliance Association suggested that the government should follow the practice of the Hohhot city, the capital of the Autonomous Region of Mongolia Interior, which offers a unique subsidy worth 10,000 Renminbis to couples who have a child. When couples have two children receive about 50,000 Renminbis over 5 years, and if they have three children receive 100,000 Renminbis over 10 years. Other requests In addition to the subsidy, associations officials argued that it is also important for the government to launch other measures to create a “more favorable environment” to increased birth rate. Loi I Weng suggested to the government to subsidize companies to implement work measures to support workers' families. In addition, the official considers that the government extend the license of maternity and paternity so that residents have less concerns about birth. Tam Sio Pang also wants the extent of maternity and paternity license and argues that maternity leave should be increased to 90 days compared to 70 days. Tam Sio Pang also suggested that the government increase vacancies in subsidized day care centers, as well as a gradual integration of child care services into the free education system.

item.title: Work | Leong Sun Iok wants protection for “false collaborators”
item.description:
The Fan deputy warns of the abuse of the independent work regime, which can be used by employer entities to avoid obligations, such as the acquisition of insurance
Deputy Leong Sun IOK intends that the government present new measures to protect “false employees”, that is, workers who are hired for independent services on paper, but in practice they are under the authority of the employer. The subject was approached through a written interpellation, released yesterday by the office of the legislator linked to the Federation of Macao Workers Associations (Faom). According to the scenario reported by Leong Sun Iok, it is becoming increasingly normal in Macau employers to resort to false employees, as "the market is limited and many people can only work this way." Without options, workers end up accepting the proposals. Under normal conditions, employees provide a service, and can choose when and how they work, being the most relevant to present the result for which they were hired. However, under the conditions reported by the deputy, in practice, workers are required to follow working hours established by the boss and his instructions, typical characteristics of the dependent worker regime. For the bosses, although this performance is illegal, the regime has the advantage of allowing expenses arising from the guarantee of labor rights. As such, Leong Sun Iok asks the executive to "verify that employers are resorting to this possibility as a means to run away from the responsibilities and duties of the employment relationship." One more study The deputy of the parliamentary bench of Faom asks to follow the example of the interior of China, to increase the protection of these workers. To this end, it argues that it is necessary to “study how to ensure workers' professional guarantees on their own and liberal professionals”, and “encourage employers to acquire work insurance for their workers with service contracts”. The member of the Legislative Assembly also asks the government to be aware of the emergence of “new employment modalities”. At the interpetement, it is also requested to perform “an inquiry into the number and types of workers on their own and existing liberal professionals” in the territory to “safeguard the professional rights and interests of workers”. On the other hand, Leong indicates that in Macau there is always an employment contract, regardless of the designation of the contract, when it is required to the “collaborator” who is “available” to perform the duties at the employer's request. Therefore, it asks the government if it will issue clear instructions and strengthen disclosure actions on the Macao labor regime to “avoid breach of law by employers and safeguard workers' rights and interests”.

item.title: MNE | Sam Hou Fai gathers with Deputy Minister Hua Chunying
item.description:
The chief executive received at the government headquarters the deputy minister of foreign business, Hua Chunying, to whom he requested support in the expansion of relations with the abroad. Sam Hou Fai pointed to the Portuguese -speaking, Spanish and Southeast Asia markets
The chief executive received on Sunday at the headquarters of the Government of Masters a delegation of representatives of the central government led by the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Hua Chunying, according to a statement released on Sunday night by the office of social communication. During the meeting, Sam Hou Fai and Hua Chunying exchanged impressions about the implementation of the proper diversification of Macau's economy, namely through strengthening and “even greater expansion of relations with the outside”. The Chief Executive highlighted Macao's “great historical and cultural wealth”, trinks that allow the territory to serve as “a platform for communication and cooperation between the country and the abroad”. Regarding government goals, Sam Hou Fai said it will “strengthen and expand their relations with the outside, especially Portuguese -speaking, Southeast Asia markets”, in order to promote “further the proper diversification of the Macao economy”. To achieve such objectives, the Leader of the Government of MSAR said it hoped "that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs could support during the process." Natural habitat In addition to the Secretary for Administration and Justice, André Cheong, also the commissioner of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Popular Republic of China in the Special Administrative Region of Macau, Liu Xianfa, attended the meeting, to whom Sam Hou Fai thanked “support on all issues related to abroad”. The chief executive also stressed that Macau is "a prosperous, stable, peaceful and harmonious society," and "a successful example of the implementation of" one country, two systems. " Hua Chunying's international notoriety rose considerably during the period when he was a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. At the end of May last year, the Council of State announced its appointment as Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs.

item.title: History | Lara Reis, Professor of Macao High School, remembered in Lisbon
item.description:
The former teacher of the Macao High School Fernando Lara Reis was remembered in the “Spring Conferences”, from the Macao Scientific and Cultural Center, by historian Celina Veiga de Oliveira. A native of Leiria, Lara Reis fought in the 1st World War and lived on Avenida da República, in the villa that today houses the Macau Red Cross house
Fernando Lara Reis was born in 1892 and died in 1950. Throughout a life filled with historical events and testimonies, the natural man of Leiria was a military man and a teacher at Macao High School, eventually making the territory his home. Lara Reis's life was recently remembered at the “Spring Conferences” of the Macao Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) by historian Celina Veiga de Oliveira, herself to her former teacher in the territory. At the session, the historian, who won the 2024 Macao International Institute Identity Award (IIM), recalled the “teacher, meritorious, driving of the arts”, and owner of “unusual knowledge”. “He was a native of Leiria and lived in Macao until his death. He attended Leiria High School, the Military College, then joined the Army School. In World War I was in Elvas, and then left to Angola in 1915 when he faced the German threat over Portuguese colonies in Africa. Observer-Aviator. ” Lara Reis was never a pilot as she wanted, having dedicated much of her life to teaching and Macao. “In 1919, Lara Reis went to Macao High School. He took a long circum-gap trip, leaving Portugal from Lisbon, going to the United States of America, crossed the entire territory and then went to Japan, down to Hong Kong and even Macau. He was a teacher in Macao, drawing, handicrafts and gymnastics until the end of his life,” said Celina Veiga de Oliveira. The historian took to the session some written testimonies left by other Macao figures who wrote about Lara Reis, namely Monsignor Manuel Teixeira in the book “Macao Lyceu”. He said he never found "no teacher who had served the High School with greater dedication." “He was a rigorous methodical teacher, whose military formation was certainly not oblivious to these characteristics. What was truly standing out was his artistic vein, because Lara Reis was always concerned with ascertaining the aesthetic meaning of the students and opening their mental horizons. This at the time when Macau was a small town. that he organized and also exhibitions by Portuguese and foreign artists he sponsored, ”he recalled. Celina Veiga de Oliveira also highlighted the words left by the writer Henrique de Senna Fernandes in an interview on "one of the greatest qualities of Lara Reis", which "besides rigor and discipline, was the consideration by the students, not distinguishing rich from the poor." Professor Lara Reis was "a party prosecutor who served to obtain tuition fees for needy students," and "he is due to the initiative of the creation of the High School Association, of which he was the first president." This association organized in the former canhydrome “sports parties of the end of the year when students performed the most difficult exercises”. Work done in Macau The historian also highlighted “another aspect of dedication to territory” by Lara Reis. The Leiriense "participated in the First World War and this led him to interest all those who were incorporated into this conflict, having founded the League of the Great War fighters and had built in the cemetery of St. Miguel Archangel the monument where the bodies of combatants rest." Moreover, "another facet of his personality was a taste for travel, because he had no family and thus left for the world." "I visited museums, art schools and photographed everything I saw, having created a estate with 32 volumes that is now a heritage of Leiria." Celina Veiga de Oliveira did not forget the old “Sol Pente” villa, located in the middle-leaf zone, namely the Avenida da República, which was the house of Lara Reis, later donated to the Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Macao to “an anti-cancer clinic that was the first institution of the genre in the Portuguese colonial space”. Today this villa serves as a house to the Red Cross of Macao, and on its walls you can find a stone with the following message: “In this building legacy by the Rotary Fernando Reis to the Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Macao, it was installed at the initiative of the Rotary Club of Macao the first anti-cancer fighting center on April 15, 1951.” “Change of Ares” When Fernando Lara Reis goes to Macao, political times are troubled, with the political agitation to be lived in China after the fall of the Empire and the Republican Revolution of 1911. "In the 1920s the nationalist shock waves lived in the Canton, which sometimes haunted the Portuguese enclave quiet, but never moved with everyday life. The Portuguese administration guaranteed a standard appearance, and the parties at Christmas, Chinese New Year, the religious festivities of the Catholic community and the Chinese population were habitual." Celina Veiga de Oliveira recalled that in the late 1920s, Lara Reis decided to transfer to Goa, a trip that would only accentuate her belonging to Macau. “In the late 1920s, he felt he was time to change his air and asked to be transferred to the Afonso de Albuquerque High School in Pangim, and was there between 1941 and 1945, taking the opportunity to know India, and met the whole country. Instead, with a graceful and already sick license, choosing Macau to be his last address, ”he recalled. Celina Veiga de Oliveira recordou também as palavras de Orlando Cardoso, que no artigo “Macau e o Oriente na vida de Lara Reis” falou do homem que se deslumbrou com Macau “a partir do momento em que, às 8 horas da noite de 23 de Outubro de 1919, avistou pela primeira vez o Farol da Guia, um pouco antes de se instalar no ‘New Macao Hotel’ e sorver de sentidos atentos os sons, os cheiros e as luzes desta porta of an immeasurable and fantastic Asia that he would describe to exhaustion. ” These Lara Reis testimonies are “in a remarkable set of travel books that lay virtually unexplored in all their research potentialities on the shelves of the Leiria District Archive”, and were investigated by Orlando Cardoso himself. In the same article, this one refers to a text from the newspaper “News of Macau” of January 17, 1950, about Lara Kings: “The Auster and Worsen Teacher; the tenacious and thorough tourist; the military who fought and consecrated the memory of those who fell in the field of struggle; the honest and firm friend; the lovely and humorous companion; social celibate that, despite this, did not disdain any opportunity to undo its gallants, always kind and inconsequential to any palm with a face that in the goto ”. Given the few studies that exist about Lara Reis and the estate he left, Celina Veiga de Oliveira left a suggestion: "May the CCCM get the detailed index of the Leiria Archive, so that the research is possible for any interested researchers."

item.title: Galaxy | G-Dragon starred in two concerts in June
item.description:
The Galaxy Arena, one of the main show rooms in the territory, is preparing to receive two concerts from the South Korean rapper and composer G-Dragon, integrated into the “Ubermensch” tour, which also goes through other Asian cities. This is the opportunity for the local audience to see and listen to one of the sleepless names of South Korean music
G-Dragon, Kwon Ji-Yong's stage name, is a 36-year-old South Korean rapper and songwriter who, in June, named after 7 and 8, comes Macao for two shows at the Cotai Galaxy Arena, who promise to delight fans or lovers of South Korea music. The two shows are part of the “übermensch” tour, which means superhuman, and which goes through several Asian cities, namely Tokyo, on May 10 and 11; Bulacan, in the Philippines, on May 17; Osaka, on May 25 and 26 and then Taipei, Kuala Lumpur and Jakarta, in July. Highlighted by Forbes magazine in 2016, as the most influential person in Asia's entertainment industry under 30, G-Dragon is linked to the world of the show and the arts since childhood, as his first television appearance took place on the children's “BBO BBO BBO” children's program. At the age of six he joined the children's group “Litlle Roo'ra”. Over the years he bet on rap, also becoming a composer, entrepreneur and fashion designer. His connection to hip hop was gradual, having integrated in 2006 the boys-band "Big Bang", releasing the solo album "Heartbreaker" in 2009, which included a song of the same name. Success felt right there, as it was recognized as the “album of the year” at Mnet Asian Music Awards. The following year, 2010, was already part of another musical group, the “T.O.P.”, which released an album of the same name, also another of success. The first G-Dragon worldwide diffress took place in 2013, calling itself “One of a Kind World Tour”, and that same year it released its second studio album, “Coup d'Atat”, which was also worth recognizing criticism. With regard to the musical style, G-Dragon says he is inspired by the Wu-Tang Clan group and the American Pharrell Williams, which is his "musical hero." Other hip-hop names, such as Kanye West, count on your reference list. A kind of revolution According to Tatler Asia magazine, Kwon Ji-Yong managed to innovate and “transcend the traditional borders of Asian pop star”, turning everything into “creative gold” into musical terms. It is classified by this publication as a chameleon in the music world, and in almost 20 years of career it was “a virtuous musician, provocative of fashion and an innovative entrepreneur” who caught the attention of fans. It presents “avant-garde clothing” that wear “an artistic genius whose professional trajectory permanently altered the DNA of Korean entertainment”, writes Tatler on G-Dragon. About the fashion designer aspect, it is described that G-Dragon does much more than wearing such “avant-garde clothing”, turning them into “cultural statements”, having been Chanel's first Asian global ambassador. In the fashion week in Paris, the South Korean rapper dared to wear women's tweed coats, transposing the limits of the gender. G-Dragon recently adopted an aesthetics called the "Grandma-Core", which includes the use of head scarves and a red-haired hair. It may or may not shock, but the style remains.

item.title: Taiwan | Increased defense expenses on the gutter
item.description: Taiwan announced yesterday that he will try to use accumulated surpluses in previous years to cover the increase in the defense budget announced by Taiwanese leader William Lai, who promised to increase military expenses to more than 3 percent of GDP. In a parliamentary comparison, the head of the Taiwan government's Directorate of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Chen Shu-Tzu, ensured that the executive will seek to finance this increase with an excess of 200 billion Taiwanese, without excluding the contraction of loans as a last appeal. "In general, we hope not to get into debt. But if we have to stray, we have to do so, because the defense expenses are very important," he said, quoted by the state news agency CNA. Taiwan's defense budget is currently around the Taiwanese $ 600 billion, after the oppositionist parliament, approving a number of budget cuts and freezes regarding the government's initial proposal. Lai, considered a “independentist” and a “hunting” by the Chinese government, reiterated her intention to increase Taiwan's military expenses last Thursday to more than 3 percent of GDP this year, amid added tensions between Taipei and Beijing.

item.title: PAULO MAIA AND CARMO
item.description: Zhu Houcong (1507-67), Emperor Jiajing devoting much of his time to his own person, discovered the state's affairs, delegating them in the corrupt Yan Song (1480-1567) who, among other infamies, would have a recognized righteous man who denounced him in a memorial sent to the monarch where his resignation proposed. This is called this poet literate and painter Yang Jisheng (1516-1555). The animadversion he felt in the face of injustice, risking his life to tell the truth, did not allow him to falter. Late on the night of December 2, 1553, feeling grateful for so many things that life had given him, in a conversation with his wife, Mrs. Zhang, who installed him to avoid the conflict given the impossibility of counteracting Yan Song's power, he replied that this was the way he had to pay all the assets he had received, as he recalled in a chronological biography (Nianpu). And yet, like many celebrated literati, he had also suffered exile on the distant margins of the Empire. It was in the course of one of these days in 1551 that, moved by the beauty of a landscape, made the painting traveling along the roller coaster (vertical roll, paint on paper, 147.5 x 39.5 cm, sold on Sotheby's) where he reveals his scholarship in the art of painting the literati in which the painted figure tends to the abstraction and the accompanying poem. In front of the mountain, whose name can be translated as "the heavenly beauty," he writes: «The Tianhua Mountain is not too far west of the provincial city walls,/ which chases admire these climbing blue-peeled blue clutches and rocks of a red-red!/ Towers and pavilions settle to the mutant shapes of the descent and climbed the mountain,/ shadows of flags and shamelies up and down the trees. shining against the vision of the clean sky,/ clouds entering; One could catch one with the sleeve. Yang Jisheng made in this painting a literate traveling in a river on a vessel that is suddenly alerted by the boatman who with a staff points to houses nested on the mountain. As on an album page that signed Jiaoshan, "Pepper Mountain" (PAPER, 27 x 35 cm ink, sold in the auctioneer Nagel) represented a home hung on top of a mountain, would say the figuration of its search for a place in the world, which would after all to refuse it. In the night that preceded his execution he wrote a famous pair of verses, in a practice known as Juemingshi, "poem of a cut life", which seeks to make a brief reflection on the meaning of his own life: "Iron Shoulders, to carry the length and the way,/ the pungent hand to writing ingeniously."

item.title: Today Macau
item.description: The Japanese government announced yesterday that it presented a formal protest to China for “misrepresented” observations made by Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba during a meeting with Chinese foreign minister Wang Yi. Wang and Ishiba met last Friday in Tokyo, at a reception of courtesy organized by the Japanese leader, on the eve of a trilateral meeting between the Japan, South Korea and China foreign ministers, with the aim of promoting future cooperation between the three neighboring countries. After the meeting, the Chinese Foreign Ministry issued a statement stating that Ishiba "fully recognizes the important meaning" of the four documents signed between the two nations, when the deciplind of diplomatic relations in 1972, and that the Japanese leader "respects the positions defined by the Chinese party." Japan urged Beijing to “immediately withdraw” the statement, which “does not resist” the facts, yesterday said Japanese government spokesman Yoshimasa Hayashi at a press conference. Hayashi considered "unfortunate" that the Chinese government issued a statement that "does not correspond to the truth." The Japanese Foreign Ministry also condemned the Chinese statement in a note, stating that during the meeting with Wang, Ishiba “stressed the need to reduce concerns” in bilateral relations, including “the situation in the east of China”, “ensuring the safety of Japanese citizens in China” and raising Chinese restrictions on Japanese seafood importation.

item.title: Public Hiring | New regime “is on the good way,” says lawyer
item.description:
Marco Caldeira, a lawyer and auxiliary teacher at the University of Lisbon Faculty of Law, argues that the proposed public hiring law, under analysis in the specialty in Hemiciclo, is “on the good way” regarding the attempt to “promote transparency and competition and bet on digitization”. The theme was discussed last week at the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center
The proposal of public hiring, currently under analysis in the specialty in the First Permanent Commission of the Legislative Assembly (AL), was one of the topics addressed in the “Spring Conferences”, at the Macao Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) last week. The author of the lecture, the lawyer and teacher Marco Caldeira, made praise for the diploma for his attempt to reform and innovation in many respects. "Although not perfect, the bill under discussion is justified by the need to update legislation that was approved four decades ago. It is a proposal that seems to point in the good way, with an effort to codify the regime, promote transparency and competition and bet on digitization," said the professor at the University of Lisbon Law School (FDUL) to HM. In addition, Marco Caldeira understands that the diploma, and the content proposed by the government, aims to "follow what are good practices adopted in Europe and the West in general." "It is also very commendable that the proposal was prepared following a serious and participated procedure of public consultation, which gave the opportunity to economic operators and contracting entities to identify deficiencies in current legislation and make suggestions," added Marco Caldeira. At the CCCM session, the FDUL professor also pointed out that the concern [demonstrated, in the diploma] with the competition and transparency of the procedures ”, as well as“ the focus on training in the use of databases, as well as the focus on centralization ”. The teacher also understood that, in this bill, the Portuguese regime "can help, because the practice followed in Portugal, and legislative evolutions, have useful teachings that, with proper adaptations, can be transposed to Macao." Positive points In the presentation at CCCM, Marco Caldeira highlighted several positive aspects of the current law proposal, namely “the express determination of inapplicability to certain contracts”, or the fact that “fundamental principles of public hiring” are established. It is also required with the new law “qualifications to candidates and competitors” of public tenders, and there is also “the clarification and standardization of the types of public hiring procedures”. Thus, a “centralized hiring regime” is created, as well as regulating “award criteria” in competitions, and the creation of an exclusive website for the public hiring area is also foreseen. Marco Caldeira also drew attention to the real need of this diploma, as public hiring was legislated with various diplomas, including two decrees of 1984 and 1985, which established, respectively, the expenditure regime with works and service acquisitions, and the process of acquisition of goods and services. Such diplomas were “undone of reality” of Macao, even though the 1984 decree was reviewed in 2021, the teacher considered. Marco Caldeira also considered that the process of reviewing this diploma has been “lengthy”, as the public consultation took place between November 6, 2018 and January 4, 2019, and a later report was prepared, but the truth is that the proposal has been under analysis since December 2023, having been voted generally on January 11 last year. What has to change In the same session, the causal and university professor also highlighted the points already addressed by the first Standing Commission of AL regarding the necessary changes to legislate in the area of ​​public hiring. It was imposed “expressly consecrating fundamental legal principles, such as economy, efficiency and effectiveness, as well as publicity and transparency”, and there is also “a lack of regulation of public hiring policies”. There was also the “need to promote transparency in public hiring procedures” and ensure “greater protection of loyal competition”. There was also “lack of rigorous and explicit regulation on the composition and operation of the proposals evaluation committees” submitted to a public tender, and there is “lack of explicit demands on the qualifications and capabilities of candidates and competitors in hiring procedures”. Other gaps point to “insufficient regulation and transparency in the evaluation and adjudication procedures”, or “lack of explicit regulation on proposals presentation with an abnormally low price”. It was still necessary to “improve the sanctioning and inspection regime”, as well as bet on “regulation that promotes the development of electronic hiring”. Says the executive Looking at the justification of the law proposal, submitted by the Executive to AL, it is read that one of the great reasons for his presentation was even the legislative dispersion that was verified and the misfit over the current reality. "The nuclear part of these diplomas was prepared in the mid-1980s, and has been in force for over 30 years. A significant part of the provisions of other legal diplomas already has an obvious divergence regarding the needs of Macao's current socioeconomic development, the efficiency of public administration management and the reinforcement of transparency and supervision," he reads. According to the executive, "given that public hiring involves the use of the public purse, it is essential to review these regimes in order to meet the needs of the society of our day." Thus, in this law proposal, “the process and regime of expenses and acquisitions of goods and services” are regulated, with some provisions of a 1999 law, as “the provisions related to the public works contract regime have a high degree of specialization and are still effective”. It is intended, with the new law of public hiring, to “guarantee justice, impartiality in the evaluation of proposals”, defining “expressly aid criteria and rigorously determining the rules of conduct of workers and members of the opening and evaluation of proposals” subjected to contest, so that “excerpt their functions impartially and entirely”. Thus, it is foreseen that “contracting entities must adequately publicize the informative elements related to public hiring procedures”. They are “those related to the public tender, the clarifications provided, the rectification of documents, the extension of the deadline for the presentation of proposals, the causes for non -adjudication, the decision to annul the procedure and the award decision”. In order to guarantee loyal competition, the government wants to ensure that all entities interested in participating in a competition have “the broader access” to all procedures, prohibiting “all acts, agreements or practices that can prevent, false or restrict competition”. Moreover, there is the “principle of impartiality”, which determines that “the program of procedures, book of charges or other documents, made by the contracting party, cannot contain any clause designed to favor or harm a particular interested party”.

item.title: Aviation | Maria José de Freitas regrets removal of panels from the airport
item.description:
The first attempts to establish in Macao airlines in the early twentieth century were approached by historian Célia Reis in the “Spring Conferences” of the Macao Scientific and Cultural Center. The architect Maria José de Freitas regretted the removal of panels from Macao International Airport that told this same story
Between the departure of the plane and the entrance to Macao International Airport (AIM) was a corridor that told the history of civil and military aviation from the territory of the early twentieth century. The project of this area of ​​the airport is by the studio of architect Maria José de Freitas, which regrets the removal of the panels and historical information that were installed in 2013. The architect left this idea in an intervention after the presentation of historian Célia Reis about the history of civil and military aviation in Macao on Monday, on the occasion of the “Spring Conferences” that take place at the Macao Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) in Lisbon. “We decided to tell the story of Aviation in Macao in this corridor, with a great extent, although at the time there was little documentation about it. I discovered some information in a work by Luís Andrade de Sá. We collected texts and images and put it all on the walls of this corridor, and that was there for a while.” "With a new direction [at AIM], I was asked how I could prove that all these events had happened. I had documentation in Portuguese, but I had nothing in Chinese and English, and at a time when I moved to Portugal on vacation, I saw, when I returned to Macau, who had removed all the information and images from this corridor. This story is unfortunate," he added. The architect added that she would like the history of the early days of Aviation in Macao to be told in these same walls. "It would be important to realize where there is more information, so that they realize the history of aviation in Macao, which was a pioneer. There was, for example, an aviation hangar near the mud houses, and there are a series of references linked to the history of this land that should be made visible at the airport, in the rooms, for example. This story should be told and things should be placed in the right place," he said. Ricou plans Célia Reis, historian and teacher, is developing an investigation project around the early days of aviation in Macao and this was the theme that led to the “spring conferences” on Monday, with the session “Aviation and Air Navigation in Macao in the 1920s-a process of colonial innovation”. Célia Reis spoke of a time when aviation began to be important to China for security reasons, and also begins to be thought to Macau. In this process, there is a personality whose name is important, a Hong Kong -born Frenchman: Charles William Ricou, a engineering and aviation pilot. From November 1919 the possibility of “establishing an air career between Macao, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Philippines, Java, India” began to equate, from November 1919, the possibility of Macaoi, Shanghai, Java, India, "contacting local government entities to obtain facilities and agreements. Célia Reis explained that Ricou intended to form two airlines, the “Far East Aviation Company”, with “a much wider connection, reaching Manila”, and another to connect Macau, Hong Kong and Cantão, named “Macau Aerial Transport Company”. This company "was constituted in Hong Kong, with a capital of $ 50,000, and had as founding partners personalities from Macau, such as Humberto de Avelar, Rodrigues dos Santos, Francisco Nolasco and Francisco da Silva". The historian also said in the presentation that the idea "was to complete the rest of the capital necessary with low value actions so that they could be bought by all [the inhabitants] in Macao." "There is even the appeal of the company's board of directors for the Macanese to subscribe to capital, showing that the company was extremely important for the inhabitants of Macao, highlighting its patriotic value, of solidarity with progress," he added. "Several voices demonstrated at that time that the company's commercial success, at first, could be little or none, although it was thought that the company could have some profits, having the ability to transport the air mail. However, this transportation capacity would be extremely limited, as the number of mail objects to transport from Macau was 24 letters a day," said Célia Reis. At the time it was thought that Macau would be a pioneer, because "it would be the first territory to the East to have an aviation company", something that would "bring more visitors and increase trade." The Government of Macao, then led by Governor Correia da Silva, "gives in to the company's appeals, granting various facilities, such as the permission to build a provisional hangar on public ground that was vacant or from sea access infrastructure." In addition, “exemption from payment of the fuel storage tax” was allowed. Thus, Macao even had hydroavião and 21 American airmen hired by the company. "It was considered that it was the largest load of air material exported by the United States of America (USA), all brought to Macao." Then the company tries to organize itself, "even asking for space on Taipa Island, designed to have definitive hangars, although provisional concessions have existed." In this context, he recalled the historian, "there were subsidies, a contract for the transportation of postal bags", to "allow a development of air navigation." Impasses to the end In May 1920, a new worldwide aviation convention emerged, to which Portugal adheres, which causes the “Macau Aerial Transport Company” to be nationalized. The project comes to advance, but quickly retreats. “The airline therefore accesses the condition of obtaining a subsidy, and having four aircraft available for military service in Macau, if necessary. The issue of defense was always present. There was then some disagreement between the conditions required by the company and those that the governor understood were necessary. In addition, the government of Macao needed the Lisbon authorization for the operation of the airline. Advance, and this one begins to negotiate with the company. But voices begin to emerge in Lisbon that will make things change. ” This is the idea that the US would be showing hidden interests through the establishment of the company. "[In Lisbon] it is fear that this is the found form of an American aviation company to settle in Macao, Portuguese territory, by different ways." First, Lisbon forbids, retreating in the negotiations, and the next governor, Rodrigo Rodrigues, "is not in accordance with the company, understanding that it will not be viable," which leads to the entire project and dialogue to be suspended. Célia Reis also pointed out that "the government of Correia da Silva has undergone several difficulties in these years, in terms of security", having occurred "very serious incidents in the relationship between Portugal and China". “For this reason, the governor considered that having airplanes was extremely important because, at this moment, China was also resorting to aviation. The authorities of Portugal, however, considered that the planes of Macao would be of no importance, comparing with the set of aircraft that would have China or even Japan. When permission for the constitution of the airline in Macao, Lisbon understands that the territory could have in a worrying situation and planes could have functions with planes Military, even if there were few, ”explained the historian. The project would fall, however, by land.

item.title: The garden of Almerindo in Timor-Leste can be watered from Portugal or England
item.description: The Garden of the Timorese Almerindo Fernandes in Lautém, 231 kilometers east from Dili, can be watered from Portugal or England, after the civil engineer applied new technologies to the agricultural sector. Almerindo Fernandes, 30, has a degree in Civil Engineering and for years has worked on rural road construction projects, but the 'animal' for agriculture spoke louder and today owns Timor-Leste's first 'smart farm'. In Lautém, Almerindo Fernandes has about two hectares of terrain, where he planted eggplant, tomatoes and other vegetables, which watering through an intelligent irrigation system that controls through a platform on his mobile phone. "It means that in Portugal or England we can water the garden with the mobile phone. It's the modern world, the world of technology, digitization. It's the opportunity to use technology, using the mobile phone to water my garden," he told Lusa. "It is a great opportunity to use technology to modernize agricultural productions," he said. With about 1.3 million inhabitants, the agricultural sector in Timor-Leste is vital to the economy of the country, but production is low and did not follow the growth of the population. According to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, more than 70% of the Timorese population lives in rural areas and most practice subsistence agriculture. Almerindo Fernandes started the activity in 2017 with the money he was sparing while working as a civil engineer and today sells his production to the school lunch program, the Armed Forces and the markets of his municipality. “So far it was a private activity, but the government is supporting the expansion of the project to the other municipalities of the country,” explained Almerindo Fernandes. The support was achieved after presenting the project to the vice-prime minister, coordinating minister of social affairs and Minister of Rural Development and Community Housing, Mariano Assanami Sabino, who eventually hired him as a specialized technician to bring the concept to the rest of the country. “The government recognizes the creativity of young people and all citizens who have creative initiatives. It is a great opportunity and the government is supporting the transformation of the garden into a youth formation center,” explained Almerindo Fernandes. In the garden, Almerindo Fernandes already has to work four people permanent and then hire others to plant, take the vegetables and do the maintenance, and at the same time gives training to young people who study agriculture. Now, according to the civil engineer, the garden also serves to do experiences to improve the system, that is, to make it more efficient and effective, with “little spent and greater performance”. "It is the principle of modernization, increased production, minimal cost is the purpose of the intelligent garden system and it is a theory we have to adapt to Timor to develop the country," he said.

item.title: History | Lara Reis, Professor of Macao High School, remembered in Lisbon
item.description:
The former teacher of the Macao High School Fernando Lara Reis was remembered in the “Spring Conferences”, from the Macao Scientific and Cultural Center, by historian Celina Veiga de Oliveira. A native of Leiria, Lara Reis fought in the 1st World War and lived on Avenida da República, in the villa that today houses the Macau Red Cross house
Fernando Lara Reis was born in 1892 and died in 1950. Throughout a life filled with historical events and testimonies, the natural man of Leiria was a military man and a teacher at Macao High School, eventually making the territory his home. Lara Reis's life was recently remembered at the “Spring Conferences” of the Macao Scientific and Cultural Center (CCCM) by historian Celina Veiga de Oliveira, herself to her former teacher in the territory. At the session, the historian, who won the 2024 Macao International Institute Identity Award (IIM), recalled the “teacher, meritorious, driving of the arts”, and owner of “unusual knowledge”. “He was a native of Leiria and lived in Macao until his death. He attended Leiria High School, the Military College, then joined the Army School. In World War I was in Elvas, and then left to Angola in 1915 when he faced the German threat over Portuguese colonies in Africa. Observer-Aviator. ” Lara Reis was never a pilot as she wanted, having dedicated much of her life to teaching and Macao. “In 1919, Lara Reis went to Macao High School. He took a long circum-gap trip, leaving Portugal from Lisbon, going to the United States of America, crossed the entire territory and then went to Japan, down to Hong Kong and even Macau. He was a teacher in Macao, drawing, handicrafts and gymnastics until the end of his life,” said Celina Veiga de Oliveira. The historian took to the session some written testimonies left by other Macao figures who wrote about Lara Reis, namely Monsignor Manuel Teixeira in the book “Macao Lyceu”. He said he never found "no teacher who had served the High School with greater dedication." “He was a rigorous methodical teacher, whose military formation was certainly not oblivious to these characteristics. What was truly standing out was his artistic vein, because Lara Reis was always concerned with ascertaining the aesthetic meaning of the students and opening their mental horizons. This at the time when Macau was a small town. that he organized and also exhibitions by Portuguese and foreign artists he sponsored, ”he recalled. Celina Veiga de Oliveira also highlighted the words left by the writer Henrique de Senna Fernandes in an interview on "one of the greatest qualities of Lara Reis", which "besides rigor and discipline, was the consideration by the students, not distinguishing rich from the poor." Professor Lara Reis was "a party prosecutor who served to obtain tuition fees for needy students," and "he is due to the initiative of the creation of the High School Association, of which he was the first president." This association organized in the former canhydrome “sports parties of the end of the year when students performed the most difficult exercises”. Work done in Macau The historian also highlighted “another aspect of dedication to territory” by Lara Reis. The Leiriense "participated in the First World War and this led him to interest all those who were incorporated into this conflict, having founded the League of the Great War fighters and had built in the cemetery of St. Miguel Archangel the monument where the bodies of combatants rest." Moreover, "another facet of his personality was a taste for travel, because he had no family and thus left for the world." "I visited museums, art schools and photographed everything I saw, having created a estate with 32 volumes that is now a heritage of Leiria." Celina Veiga de Oliveira did not forget the old “Sol Pente” villa, located in the middle-leaf zone, namely the Avenida da República, which was the house of Lara Reis, later donated to the Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Macao to “an anti-cancer clinic that was the first institution of the genre in the Portuguese colonial space”. Today this villa serves as a house to the Red Cross of Macao, and on its walls you can find a stone with the following message: “In this building legacy by the Rotary Fernando Reis to the Santa Casa da Misericórdia de Macao, it was installed at the initiative of the Rotary Club of Macao the first anti-cancer fighting center on April 15, 1951.” “Change of Ares” When Fernando Lara Reis goes to Macao, political times are troubled, with the political agitation to be lived in China after the fall of the Empire and the Republican Revolution of 1911. "In the 1920s the nationalist shock waves lived in the Canton, which sometimes haunted the Portuguese enclave quiet, but never moved with everyday life. The Portuguese administration guaranteed a standard appearance, and the parties at Christmas, Chinese New Year, the religious festivities of the Catholic community and the Chinese population were habitual." Celina Veiga de Oliveira recalled that in the late 1920s, Lara Reis decided to transfer to Goa, a trip that would only accentuate her belonging to Macau. “In the late 1920s, he felt he was time to change his air and asked to be transferred to the Afonso de Albuquerque High School in Pangim, and was there between 1941 and 1945, taking the opportunity to know India, and met the whole country. Instead, with a graceful and already sick license, choosing Macau to be his last address, ”he recalled. Celina Veiga de Oliveira recordou também as palavras de Orlando Cardoso, que no artigo “Macau e o Oriente na vida de Lara Reis” falou do homem que se deslumbrou com Macau “a partir do momento em que, às 8 horas da noite de 23 de Outubro de 1919, avistou pela primeira vez o Farol da Guia, um pouco antes de se instalar no ‘New Macao Hotel’ e sorver de sentidos atentos os sons, os cheiros e as luzes desta porta of an immeasurable and fantastic Asia that he would describe to exhaustion. ” These Lara Reis testimonies are “in a remarkable set of travel books that lay virtually unexplored in all their research potentialities on the shelves of the Leiria District Archive”, and were investigated by Orlando Cardoso himself. In the same article, this one refers to a text from the newspaper “News of Macau” of January 17, 1950, about Lara Kings: “The Auster and Worsen Teacher; the tenacious and thorough tourist; the military who fought and consecrated the memory of those who fell in the field of struggle; the honest and firm friend; the lovely and humorous companion; social celibate that, despite this, did not disdain any opportunity to undo its gallants, always kind and inconsequential to any palm with a face that in the goto ”. Given the few studies that exist about Lara Reis and the estate he left, Celina Veiga de Oliveira left a suggestion: "May the CCCM get the detailed index of the Leiria Archive, so that the research is possible for any interested researchers."

item.title: IC | Launched book on the historical roots of Rua das Estlagês
item.description:
“In Search of Its Roots - An Illustrated History of Street of Estalagins” is the name of the work Bilingual, launched in digital format, which tells the story of this historic street of Macao, revealing the business that survived the passage of time. Production was in charge of the Macao Artists Society, with the support of the Cultural Institute and Sands China
The history serpes through the stalage street since the end of the nineteenth century. The narrow artery has always been the scene of an intense social and commercial rebolement and it was where Sun Yat-Sen, considered the father of modern China and the Republican Revolution, opened pharmacies and drugstores, especially from 1893. Over the years, Rua das Estalagem, in Porto, was a living example of commerce, and the Portuguese governors were progressively expanding the street, composed of the street Chinese -style buildings and temples, such as the Temple of the Bazaar and Goddess Temple NOVA WO. All these pieces of history are now counting on the digital publication “In Search of Its Roots - An Illustrated History of Rua das Estlagês”, a work produced by the Society of Macao Artists and authored by Siguo Chen in Shirley Lule's texts and illustrations. Those responsible for the edition are the Cultural Institute (IC) and the game operator Sands China. According to a press release of Sands China, the book, in Chinese and English, intends to “highlight the fascinating past of the historic Macau Street and the beauty of its legacy”, containing interviews with street -related figures, whether merchants or residents. Thus, it is intended to bring “residents and visitors to rediscover the preciousness of the centenary stores and the cultural heritage of the street through legendary stories” so that they can “widen their understanding of the transformation of the neighborhood and its inhabitants”. The content of the book results from “close conversations with representatives of associations, business entities and residents of the neighborhood,” having dozens of oral stories that can easily be lost if not recorded. This work is not closed in the digital world, having been printed to appear in the public libraries of Macao and schools, in order to “promote the meaning of cultural heritage and enhance mutual ties among the people of Macao”, intending to be “a valuable community resource to deepen the understanding and appreciation of Macao and the street”. 200 years of history One of the highlights given in the book is to the textile sector that has always predominated on Rua das Estlagenas. In the chapter entitled "Two Centuries of Prosperity: Spinning A Legacy in the Textiles Trade" [two centuries of prosperity: the construction of a legacy in the textile trade], it is read that "Street of Estlagins has always been a center for the textile industry." In the years when the textile sector had a larger presence in the territory, between the 70's and 90's, "Rua housed more than 20 stores with factory products, including three spaces from the Veng On Farm Store." “Around 30 businesses related to these stores, such as tailors, clothing stores, western products and funeral ornament stores, which brought a reputation to the street,” he reads. In Rua das Estlagenas “Tissue trade is over 200 years old,” says the same text. Other chapters of the book speak of the presence of the republican revolutionary in Macao in “The Starting Point of Sun Yat-Sen’s Story” [The Starting Point of the story of Sun Yat-Sen] or stories of street-linked personalities and their commerce. In the conclusion of the work, it refers that after the transition, the street "faced new challenges: the global financial crisis, the SARS epidemic, the COVID-19, and the uncertainty of the economy, leaving the need for renewal again." "In the past, the business has flourished, by themselves, thanks to hard work and resilience. But nowadays the community joins with a shared vision, actively planning [the development of the street] with the support of the Macao government and the integrated resort companies. With these efforts, there is a sense of hope that the street of the stalage will briefly recover its old vitality, being ready for a new era." Visão institucional IC President Deland Leong Wai Man pointed out that the book results from the “weighted effort to widen the discussion around preservation and revitalization [of the street],” according to the same press release. "Street renewal is expected to inspire more people to learn about the historic neighborhoods of Macao and participate in their preservation, combining ideas and resources to ensure that the city's culture and history continue to prosper during generations," he said. In turn, Wilfred Wong, CEO of Sands China, argued that "Street of Estalagues is a microcosm of Macao itself, a place where a rich story meets a modern future." "The walls of their alleys witnessed the transformation of Macao, and their stories and people deserve to be remembered, as they are precious sources of Macao's cultural heritage. Our effort to publish the book was possible thanks to the collaboration of our local team to conduct interviews with owners of historical stores, create illustrations and take pictures, among other works," he said. New facades It is recalled that this publication arises after the Government was announced by the Sands performance at the Rua das Estalagens Revitalization Plan, namely with the “Entrepreneurs Recruitment Program for Rua das Estlagês”, launched in April last year. The game operator explains that the seven businesses selected for the initiative “have been opening through phases, bringing energy to the zone along with other new businesses, providing a platform for young ambitious entrepreneurs to realize their dreams”. In addition, the game operator intends to revitalize stores' façades “with drawings that enhance their characteristics, resonating the history of the street and the city”. For this initiative, Sands has also collaborated with the Macao Artist Society, and the drawings will be created by two young local artists, Chek On Law and Sit Kat Kit. "The aim is that, with a collective effort like this, the community can rediscover the history of the street and learn about its past stories and stores through the visual interpretations of these local artists from Macao and their perceptions of the territory," he reads. Siguo Chen, the book's author, is a veteran journalist with a career of over 60 years who has been deeply linked to the media area in Macau and Hong Kong.

item.title: Sun Yat-Sen | Marked centenary of the death of the “father of modern China”
item.description:
Sun Yat-Sen died on March 12, 1925. Unavoidable figure in the political history of modern China and the father of the movement that led to the fall of the imperial regime, Sun Yat-Sen was celebrated yesterday in Guangzhou, where he was born, Beijing and Taiwan
The first president of China post-imperial and considered the father of the country's modern era, Sun Yat-Sen, was remembered yesterday in mainland China and Taiwan, the 100th anniversary of his death. In Beijing, there was a “brief and solemn ceremony” of honor to Sun in Beijing Park that has its name. Authorities and “people from all the sectors of society” were present, kept silence and made three venias in front of their statue, the Xinhua official news agency said. The Chinese Academy of History praised the political figure in his Weibo account, describing him as "a great national hero, a great patriot and a major precursor of the Democratic Revolution of China." The city of Guangzhou, the capital of Guangdong Province, where Sun Yat-Sen was born, inaugurated on Tuesday an exhibition of old objects related to the man who was one of the promoters of the revolution that overthrew the Qing Dynasty (1644-1911). The Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Building in the city welcomed the first performance of a musical based on the revolutionary's youth. In Guangzhou, where there is also a university named Sun Yat-Sen, this exhibition is exhibited, which includes objects such as the Sun Yat-Sen Graduation Exam report at the College of Medicine for Chinese, in Hong Kong, from 1892. The certificate of marriage between Sun Yat-Sen and Soong Ching-Ling is also highlighted in 1915, a woman later, woman later, Vice-President of China during the government of Mao Tse-Tung, embracing communism. In the same exhibition you can also see the bronze bust of Sun Yat-Sem itself, made by order of the Japanese friend Umeya Shokichi in 1929. The "father" of modern China was also remembered in Taiwan, with a ceremony by the Sun Yat-sen memorial in Taipei, where flowers were deposited and express respect. Double memories Despite founding, in 1919, the Kuomitang, which would become the main rival of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), Sun is remembered in both mainland China and Taiwan. The Board of State's Taiwan Cabinet stated that Sun Yat-Sen “sought China's national unity and revitalization throughout his life,” appealing at the same time to the “compatriots of Taiwan to join us in the inheritance of his legacy” and to “oppose secession” of the island. Born in 1866, Sun studied medicine in Hong Kong - then a British colony - and, after leading several revolts, gained notoriety as a revolutionary leader and as a driving force of an attempt to modernize the country. In 1911, the Xinhai Revolution led to the fall of the Qing and Sun Yat-Sen dynasty was appointed provisional president of the New Republic of China in January 1912, but quickly gave power to the country's main military leader, Yuan Shikai, who, far from consolidating republican ideals, dissolved the parliament in 1914 and proclaimed herself in 1915, annulling Grande, annul Part of the democratic progress by which Sun had fought. From then on, he continued to promote his ideal of a unified and republican China, reorganizing the KMT and seeking international support for his cause. In 1923, he established an alliance with the newly founded CCP and received the support of the Soviet Union to reinforce the political movement. However, he failed to consolidate a stable government before his death in 1925. A LIFE OF FIGHT In the work “Sisters Soong-the oldest, younger and redest,” by Jung Chang, some details of Sun Yat-Sen's life are described before embracing the revolutionary cause and the way he left his parents' house in Guangzhou, looking for a better life. The place of destination was Hawaii, which on July 4, 1894 declared itself as a Republic, an event that, according to the book, "helped shape today's China." “A 27-year-old radical Chinese, Sun Yat-sen, landed in the archipelago and entered a world where the word 'republic' was in every mouth,” he is described. In China, the agitation against the power of the empire became strong. The Republic "was a new concept," for "the monarchy was the only political system that China knew." "At the time, the country was governed by the Manchu dynasty," the Manchus "were not natural from China, but they had conquered the territory in the mid -seventeenth century." "Since they did not get more than one percent of the population, they were considered a minority of foreign rulers and had never been lacking opposition from the native rebels Han. Sun was one of them," he describes in the same work. Sun Yat-Sen was "a low, dark man with well-proposed and pleasant traits." Its home village, Cuiheng, had soils inappropriate for agriculture, which provided “a life of extreme misery” to those who lived there. As such, the revolutionary's family did not escape adverse conditions. In his first escape from the context of poverty, Sun went to Hong Kong, finding shelter to the diocesan school and boys orphanage, then accepted a marriage arranged by the family as a gimmick to return to the village. Sun Yat-Sen married Mu-Zhen, had children, but was an absent figure and something carefree in the face of family responsibilities, traveling the world to seek support for the revolution he wanted for China. Jung Chang's work describes how Sun's course linked to the "three sisters," Ei-Ling, May-Ling and Ching-Ling. Charlie Soong funded and supported Sun Yat-Sen in her revolutionary causes, one of her daughters, Ei-Ling, became the republican secretary. This, although married, had made attempts to approach loving and EI-Ling, but eventually had a relationship with Ching-Ling, who was nationalist, but later embraced communism, being known as the "red sister." Ching-ling was also known as the Madame Sun Yat-Sen, but at the time of Sun Yat-Sen's death, the relationship between them had cooled. After the establishment of the Popular Republic of China, Ching-Ling was vice president of the country, between 1949 and 1954, and then between 1959 and 1975, and was vice president of the Permanent Commission of the National Assembly. Passage through macau Moreover, Sun Yat-Sen's life crossed Macao several times, where he lived a short time, unlike his woman, Mu-Zhen, and the children who remained in the territory longer. To remember the short period in which the Republican lived in the territory, at the time under Portuguese administration, the memorial house of dr. Sun Yat-Sen, where he "witnesses the short but significant stay in Macao in the early twentieth century when, running away from the power of imperial mandarins, tried to move his supporters forces in order to implement a new regime in China." “In Macau received support from some friends who were illustrious and influential figures of social and political life at the time,” reads the description of the museum. Another interesting detail of the 1911 Republican Revolution is the proximity of dates against the establishment of the Republic in Portugal, which took place on October 5, 1910. Macau, in the midst of events in China and Portugal, was only aware that the constitutional monarchy had fallen into Lisbon thanks to the sending of a telegram published in an official bulletin on October 10, 1910, changing the governor in this context.
